questions.question_text: Which programmable API allows the service provider to plan and optimize the automation of network operations and achieve dosed-loop operations?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Cross Works is a suite, to cover all the aspects mention in the question, the complete suite must be selected

Selected Answer: C
Cisco Crosswork Network Automation is a microservices platform that brings together streaming telemetry, big data, and model-driven application programming interfaces (APIs) to redefine service provider network operations. Cisco Crosswork Network Automation offers a platform for customers and partners to collaborate on and build an application ecosystem around on-box innovation.

The Cisco Cisco Crosswork Network Automation product suite is a highly scalable and efficient operations automation framework. It enables service providers to quickly deploy intent-driven, closed-loop operations.
Cisco Crosswork Network Automation: The Industry’s Most Comprehensive Closed-Loop Automation Solution

Selected Answer: C
Answer A -> Network Services Orchestrator (NSO) is an industry-leading orchestration platform for hybrid networks. It provides comprehensive lifecycle service automation to enable you to design and deliver high-quality services faster and more easily. NSO supports the process of validating, implementing and abstracting your network config and network services, providing support for the entire transformation into intent based networking.

Answer C (Correct Answer) > https://developer.cisco.com/crosswork/ , Plan, design, implement, operate, and optimize your service provider network with Cisco Crosswork Network Automation. Cisco Crosswork is designed to help service providers gain the mass awareness, augmented intelligence, and proactive control for a comprehensive data-driven, intent-based automated network.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer with an employee ID 4402:98:032 is setting up an IS-IS network with these requirements:
• Routes with a tag of 80 and IP prefixes other than 192.168.10.20/24 must be redistributed from Level 1 into Level 2
• Route leaking must be configured from Level 2 into the Level 1 domain for routes that are tagged with only 50 or 40

Which configuration must be implemented on RB to meet the requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer: D
route-map redist1-2 permit 10
match tag 80
match ip address 152
!!tag 80 =192.168.10.30/24
!!match ip address 152=deny 192.168.10.20/24 and permit any

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Answer: D
route-map redist1-2 permit 10
match tag 80
match ip address 152
!!tag 80 =192.168.10.30/24
!!match ip address 152=deny 192.168.10.20/24 and permit any
Option D

To deny a network with the IP address range 192.168.10.0/24，you should use command like this. 
access-list 152 deny ip 192.168.10.0 0.0.0.255 any

comments.content:
I don't think there is a correct answer here, should be something missing.
either ACL change to access-list 152 deny ip 192.168.10.0 0.0.0.255 any then D
or add match tag 40 in in route-map redist1-2 to allow IP prefixes other than 192.168.10.20/24

if the requirement is 
• Routes with a tag of 80 and IP prefixes other than 192.168.10.20/24 must NOT be redistributed from Level 1 into Level 2
then for sure C is correct

discussion.content: Answer D, little typo in text 192.168.10.20/24 should've been 192.168.10.20/32

D is Correct : 
route-map redist1-2 permit 10 
 match ip address 152
 match tag 80

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D dahh
D is right

choices.D: Add match ip address 152 in route-map redist1-2
choices.A: Remove match tag 40 from route-map leak2-1
choices.B: Add match tag 80 in route-map leak2-1
choices.C: Change match tag 80 to match tag 50 in route-map redist1-2

discussion.content:
Answer: BD
-1) R2 is sending hello with "1699 bytes," whereas the maximum MTU is "1500 bytes.". The following link is explained very well. 
-2) If we change the MTU to "1500 bytes" on the R2 interface, then it will send hello with "1499 bytes," and it will build the neighborship if the link is not over MPLS.
-3) With Hello padding disabled on the interface Serial 2/0, the size of the Hello packet to the minimum.
-4) Thus, if you only disable the IS-IS Hello padding, it is not enough to bring up the IS-IS adjacency. The MTU must be low enough so that the MTU-sized IS-IS Hello packets are sent and received properly by the routers on either side of the link.

Selected Answer: BD
Sorry guys but it seems like answer is B, D
Adjust MTU 
Disable Hello padding so that ISIS does not detect MTU mismatches, as there wont be any need to

Selected Answer: AE
I will go for A and E
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/integrated-intermediate-system-to-intermediate-system-is-is/119399-technote-isis-00.html#:~:text=Note%3A%20Cisco%20recommends%20that%20you%20do%20not%20disable%20the%20IS%2DIS%20Hello%20padding%20in%20order%20to%20ensure%20that%20two%20routers%20form%20an%20IS%2DIS%20adjacency%20on%20a%20link%20that%20has%20mismatched%20MTU%20values%20on%20either%20side.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/integrated-intermediate-system-to-intermediate-system-is-is/119399-technote-isis-00.html
The MTU on the serial interfaces for the routers R1 and R2 are the default 1,500 bytes.

The IS-IS adjacency fails because the IS-IS Hello packets are 1,499 bytes in size. The MPLS network only allows 1,500-byte packets, minus eight bytes (two MPLS labels for the MPLS service), which equals 1,492 bytes (the packet size that is allowed to pass through). For transport of L2 over MPLS, the size of the L2 header must be subtracted from the 1,492 bytes that result as well.

choices.A: Change the hello interface timer to 10 seconds on R1
choices.D: Disable padding for hello packets under the serial interface on R2
choices.E: Enable hello packet padding globally on R1
choices.B: Change the MTU to 1500 bytes on R2
choices.C: Change R2 to an IS-IS Level 1 router

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Routers R1 and R2 are connected via a serial link and use the IS-IS routing protocol for route exchange. After a configuration change on R2, IS-IS connectivity is interrupted. A network engineer confirmed that the interfaces are in the UP state and connectivity exists between the two routers. Which two actions must the engineer perform to resolve the problem? (Choose two.)

choices.A: The PE discovers and shares routing information for the B-MAC addresses associated with local Ethernet segments.
choices.D: The PE discovers other PEs in the same Ethernet segment and elects a DF.
choices.B: The PE discovers remote ESIs and determines their redundancy mode.
choices.C: The PE discovers the remote PEs in the EVI and builds a flood list linked with the EVI.

questions.question_text: In an EVPN operation how does the PE determine and advertise Ethernet segment reachability?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Ethernet segment reachability: In multihoming scenarios, the PE auto-discovers remote PE and their corresponding redundancy mode (all-active or single-active). In case of segment failures, PEs withdraw the routes used at this stage in order to trigger fast convergence by signaling a MAC mass withdrawal on remote PEs.

Selected Answer: B
B for sure
Option B
Yes, it should be B

comments.content:
At startup, PEs exchange EVPN routes in order to advertise the following:

===VPN membership===: 
The PE discovers all remote PE members of a given EVI. In the case of a multicast ingress replication model, this information is used to build the PEs flood list associated with an EVI. BUM labels and unicast labels are exchanged when MAC addresses are learned.

===Ethernet segment reachability===: 
In multihoming scenarios, the PE auto-discovers remote PE and their corresponding redundancy mode (all-active or single-active). In case of segment failures, PEs withdraw the routes used at this stage in order to trigger fast convergence by signaling a MAC mass withdrawal on remote PEs.

===Redundancy Group membership===: 
PEs connected to the same Ethernet segment (multihoming) automatically discover each other and elect a Designated Forwarder (DF) that is responsible for forwarding Broadcast, Unknown unicast and Multicast (BUM) traffic for a given EVI.
My bad i wanted to say correct answer is B

discussion.content:
I think answer should be C.
ultihoming scenarios, the PE auto-discovers remote PE and their corresponding redundancy mode (all-active or single-active). In case of segment failures, PEs withdraw the routes used at this stage in order to trigger fast convergence by signaling a MAC mass withdrawal on remote PEs.

questions.answer_description:
IntServ follows the signaled-QoS model, where the end-hosts signal their QoS needs to the network.
Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/technologies/tk543/tk766/technologies_white_paper09186a00800a3e2f.html

Selected Answer: A
Option A is accurate as per link.
